Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Protocols in Colorectal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in multiple hospitals.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing elective colorectal surgery, with eligibility criteria including age 18-75 and ASA classification I-III.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received ERAS protocols, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of ERAS protocols compared to conventional care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the length of hospital stay (LOS), measured over 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the ERAS group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the ERAS group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The ERAS group had a significantly shorter LOS (mean difference = 2.5 days, 95% CI 1.8 to 3.2; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institute of Health.
